answers.answer: Hi,There are many possible causes of arm numbness : Remaining in the same seated or standing position for a long time ,Injury to a nerve -- for example, a neck injury may cause you to feel numbness anywhere along your arm or hand,Pressure on the spinal nerves, such as from a herniated disk ,Pressure on peripheral nerves from enlarged blood vessels, tumors, scar tissue, or infection ,Lack of blood supply to an area -- for example, cholesterol (plaque) build up from atherosclerosis in the legs can cause pain, numbness, and tingling while walking (this is called vascular claudication); frostbite can also reduce blood supply and lead to numbness ,Other medical conditions, including: Carpal tunnel syndrome (pressure on a nerve at the wrist) ,Diabetes ,Multiple sclerosis ,Seizures ,Stroke ,Transient ischemic attack (TIA), sometimes called a "mini-stroke" ,Underactive thyroid ,Raynaud's phenomenon ,Abnormal levels of calcium, potassium, or sodium in your body ,A lack of vitamin B12 or other vitamin ,Use of certain medications ,Toxic nerve damage due to lead, alcohol, or tobacco or Radiation therapy . Please consult a physician for the diagnosis . Hope this helps you . Take care and regards !

question: I've started feeling slight numbness in my left arm and hand.  I've also dealt with what I guess is indigestion for a while now.  I'm only 28 and in relatively good shape, so I like to believe my heart it ok.  I can still work out fine, or give a hard days work (sometimes just the numbness) but it's when I slow down, I feel kind of off.  Basically if I was a car, I would say my transmission was a little off.
title: slight numbness in my left arm
